reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “value-as-product-of-factors” toy model and the use of stipulated thresholds (e.g., 50% = mostly-great). That matters to one prominent intuition pump (Section 2.4) and to how the authors make ‘fragility’ vivid, but it is not the main load-bearing support for the overall ‘no easy eutopia / fussiness’ conclusion, which is also argued via historical moral catastrophe examples and (especially) the later, more systematic discussion of bounded/unbounded value functions and aggregation. So centrality is moderate. Strength is low-to-moderate: it correctly notes the product model is asserted as a modeling choice and could be wrong, but it overstates by saying the central claim “rests entirely” on stipulations and by demanding an empirical/falsifiable mechanism for a largely normative/metaethical claim. Correctness is mixed for the same reason: fair criticism of one argumentative move, but substantial mischaracterization of how much of the essay depends on it. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Multiplicative value aggregation lacks empirical or theoretical justification
